thread.title: Casino tax revenue up slightly
thread.title_full: Casino tax revenue up slightly | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: Casino tax revenue up slightly
text:
Tax revenue from Ohio’s four casinos showed a slight uptick in the third quarter, producing $66.6 million earmarked for cities, counties, schools and state agencies.
The Ohio Department of Taxation report for the period ending Sept. 30 reflected a 3.7 percent increase over the $64.2 million generated in the second quarter this year.
Because the overall increase in tax revenue was so small, however, Columbus will see $2.65 million, nearly the same amount as the previous quarter. The city will receive $1.8 million from the overall per capita distribution, plus an additional $850,155 as one of four casino host cities.
Cleveland will see $2.69 million, Cincinnati $2 million and Toledo $1.45 million, according to the taxation report available online.  
The state’s largest cities and counties get money on a per-capita basis. That totaled $7.9 million and $33.9 million, respectively, for July through September.
Another $22.6 million went into a fund distributed to public and charter schools, with $1.9 million apiece going to the Ohio Casino Control Commission and the Ohio Racing Commission. A law enforcement fund and problem gambling fund each receives $1.3 million.
The money comes from a 33-percent tax levied on casinos. The totals do not include revenue from the state’s seven horse track racinos which are regulated by the Ohio Lottery Commission.
@ohioaj
